titleInfo.title: Daryl Blacher Murray oral history interview

mods.abstract: Murray recalls her time as a student at McKinley High School from 1970 to 1974. She discusses the importance of academics, the teachers who were her role models, the popular fashions and hairstyles, the elected offices she held and honors she was bestowed, and the role that a McKinley education played in her career as a public servant. She discusses the role of athletics at McKinley, the quality of the athletic programs, and the rivalry between McKinley and Capitol High School. She ponders the influence of McKinley on Baton Rouge's history and the school's impact on the political life of African Americans in Baton Rouge.
mods.note: This collection includes materials accessioned as Mss. 4700.0687; A digital version of the transcript (pdf) exists for duplication purposes; A digital version of the audio recording (mp3) exists for duplication purposes and public access in the Special Collections Reading Room; Interview conducted by Nadia Graves.

Daryl Blacher Murray was born on April 2, 1956, in New Orleans, La., to Beverly and Harold Blacher, Sr. She is one of five children and grew up across the street from McKinley High School in Baton Rouge, La. Murray attended McKinley High School from 1970 to 1974. She served as student body president and class president, was named Most Popular and Miss Track, and was a member of the Honor Society. After graduating from McKinley, she attended Southern University and graduated with a degree in speech communication. At the time of the interview, she was employed by the East Baton Rouge Parish Planning Commission. She went on to work as the associate state director for community outreach for the AARP, and in 2009 became the director of the Bureau of Policy, Planning and Evaluation for the Louisiana Department of Social Services.

name.namePart: Louisiana State University (Baton Rouge, La.). T. Harry Williams Center for Oral History
